Typically people want to know what we do not fund, what we cannot support, what the barriers are, how the process works and all that. We do it at a national level. At a local level we have staff involved in any committees or meetings of local area groups at the local level across the city. There are multiple groups we meet, though I do not want to name them. We try to be as proactive as we can be within that system, not only with State organisations but also with NGOs and the charity sector - anybody we think is a player involved with us. Then it is at the individual officer level as well and to replicate that down. We really try to be involved in any mechanism whereby the individual community welfare officer can be involved with the crisis intervention. A good example of that is children and young person's CYPSCs, crisis intervention teams where State agencies like Tusla, the Garda and the Probation Service come together to assist a family in crisis.

A community welfare officer would be involved. There would typically be a clinical aspect to that, but there are also financial supports that the community welfare service and officer can bring to the table to help that family in need. Often, it can be small things such as a washing machine or fixing a shower. We want to be in that space. We work closely with the particular charities in that area.

There may be a cocktail of supports. An organisation might come to us to tell us it will do this if we can do that. It is about trying to get back into that space. We are actively encouraging community welfare officers to do home visits so that they understand that going to a person's home and engaging with them is important when it comes to making a decision on that person's claim. As Ms Haran said, they may visit for one purpose, and when they go into a home, they see other things we can provide support with. They can also engage with other players working in that area.
There are three layers. That is where we are at. We need to try to be as proactive as possible because we are in the business of trying to help people. That is where we are coming from.
There is no better business to be in. I have a small follow-up-----
You are out of time.

Like other speakers, I am building on points that have been made. I hope I will be able to finish. I refer to the heating supplement. It has been brought into sharp focus. I was not aware of the breadth of support offered by the payment. A person born with a congenital condition may not be in and out of hospital whereas a person who has received a recent diagnosis will be hearing more relevant and up-to-date information. There is a missing area in the information and communications piece.

The service has gathered data on those availing of the heating supplement, including those who may be able to avail of it and how many of them live in social housing. Should we consider EnergyCloud and ensure we get heat pump systems into particular areas? There is a broader conversation to be had.

The service will produce a document on the heating supplement. This needs to come out of hospitals. Not everybody is digitally savvy and people like to have that piece of paper. Those who have received news of a diagnosis are not open and attuned to everything they can avail of. It is only when they go home that people ask about this and that. People could lean on a pamphlet. Our offices would love such booklets.

About three years ago, the then Minister, Heather Humphreys, produced a fantastic easy-to-read document of everything the social welfare system provided. I had one of those booklets. It referred to the disability allowance. Is that document being updated? Where does it stand? I am sure that many new Deputies and Senators who have come to the Houses would like to have one for every member of their staff. It is the Bible of social protection. It is a really good document and I could not compliment it enough. It was available to everybody. With the permission of the Chair, it would be great to have the service give a presentation on the booklet in the audiovisual room, in conjunction with what is being developed for those who acquire a disability or receive a diagnosis, such as what is being done with the Irish Cancer Society. We could launch, or relaunch, such booklets and create awareness with the service's partners that are on the front line.

As regards those partners, I want to make a suggestion. Reference was made to hubs. We want people to have information so that they can get their payments. I am wondering about oireachtas.ie. If somebody comes to me, could I upload the information? Can I send a claim in directly and can it be assessed in a timely fashion in the same manner as hubs? Have the witnesses considered that?

I thank the Deputy for the suggestion. I am not aware of whether the easy-to-read documents have been updated, but we will take that back to our communications people. All three of us have one mission, namely, to simplify every document, letter and piece of correspondence, and make it straightforward so that people can understand it. We are very conscious that there are new communities and English is not the first language for everyone. Literacy and sending complicated letters are issues. We are all as one on that.
Regarding the upload, I am not quite sure what-----

I will explain. When I print out forms for the supplementary welfare allowance, I know I need to provide A, B and C with the application. What is required is very clear. Everything is time sensitive, though, so rather than telling a constituent that they need to make their way to Loughrea or Tuam or put it in the post, I could scan and upload the document directly to the community welfare office. That would speed up the process so that a person did not need to have two meetings. The next meeting the person would have would be about getting the support required or it would just be a communication to say that a payment would be lodged in their bank account on Friday. I am trying to sharpen the delivery of services.
I see. We mentioned we were reviewing all of the forms. We are also reviewing the processes and applications. Let us take that away and see what is possible.
We have some fantastic staff working in all of our offices who are meeting these people. I am trying to be of assistance to the person at the centre because the staff work very well with our teams.

Once an application has been submitted, customers can email additional documents . We accept documents by email, but generally what we cannot accept are screenshots. Some people try to screenshot 30 pages of a bank statement, which then have to be printed off individually and scanned as one. I have seen staff in hubs on the phone with customers to advise them how to make a document into a PDF. I am not sure whether we accept the application form by email, but additional information is accepted by email.

What I have suggested would cut out a step. It is not about trying to remove anybody from their job or anything like that. A community welfare officer might visit people living in Portumna once every three weeks on a round trip, but people cannot wait three weeks for payments. That is all I am trying to say.
Thank you very much, Senator.

May I ask a last question on housing? A number of contributors referred to housing. It is no different to the hospital scenario. How community welfare officers work with our local authorities gets a little bit lost in translation. We know from our housing statistics that we have the good, the bad and the ugly of local authorities. The information might not be getting out there. I will again refer to the man who had to choose between a floor and a fridge and whom we were asking to downsize. That is not good practice. There have to be better ways of us supporting people in moving from a three-bedroom property to a one-bedroom unit in order to make the larger property available for a family. We need to be able to tell people they can be connected and supported. I am not looking for gold standards, but for the basics to be delivered.

Okay. Thank you very much. Does the community welfare service have a good working relationship with the Money Advice & Budgeting Service, MABS? Many constituents who contact us with queries have budgeting issues. They contact MABS in the first instance and then contact the community welfare service.

As I said, we are trying not to respond solely to what the person presents. If somebody presents to us with difficulties in paying utility bills, that could be a budgeting or income issue. We have a role in linking with other agencies and providing advice to a person on the additional benefits to which they might be entitled. Everybody has made the point that, sometimes, people do not know about their entitlements. It is not our role to look solely at immediate needs, but also to tell them about things like the working family payment, etc.
Ms Goodwin might discuss MABS.

We work very closely with MABS. Our application pack has a line on it stating that if you are looking for assistance with household bills and are experiencing difficulty, please be aware MABS is available to support. We signpost MABS on all our application packs and we with closely with it. It could be that somebody has a very large bill and MABS wants them over time to budget and get the bill down. They will do it over a number of payments rather than doing it all in one go because MABS is working with them.
That is very good to hear. What is the average payment for a standard new house kit-out?
We do not have it to hand but approximately €4,500 is the average amount we issue.
How often do all the CWOs around the country get together to share experiences and have a conversation? Does that happen very regularly?

That is a difficult dynamic because we have our CWOs involved in front-line duties. For us to release staff from that has proven quite a challenge. We have not had a national meeting because there has never been an opportunity for us to down tools and bring everyone together.
You could have a couple of them all, I suppose, and divide it up.
We have done that. We have had area meetings.

We divide them up and have it. We were due to have a meeting in Mullingar with about 50 staff a couple of weeks back. Storm Claudia arrived and we had to cancel. It is just the nature of things and of the business that we are in.
We did not cancel because of the storm. We cancelled to ensure CWS was available, if necessary. They are on call this morning because of yesterday.

They are on standby in relation to any scenario that might present on a given day across the country. It happens as often as we can make them available. We have technology as well. Every Thursday morning, we have a training hour for all community welfare staff. We have video sessions with them every week of the year. They are to discuss various aspects, to bring the uniformity and standardisation we discussed and to bring in guest speakers from the Society of St. Vincent de Paul or other agencies, so they hear directly from people involved in other aspects of service delivery. Technology is of great use to us in that space.

A real positive in my community is a community welfare officer or social welfare staff visiting a town hall and having a meeting there with the active retired or the age friendly committee. That is positive because many people get to know the local person in the Intreo office or the local community welfare officer by face and name and there is an opportunity to have a discussion locally and see what is available. For me and, I think, for many other members here this morning, sometimes the barrier is finding out what information and supports are available, so I very much appreciate that.

I come back to the question of rent supplement and the interaction with the local authorities. I am conscious that, taking into account housing costs, we estimate about 200,000 children are in consistent poverty. Housing figures are not really keeping up with social housing and affordable housing demand. People are falling through the cracks. The rent supplement goes a long way in helping some of those people but the number of 6,000 suggests there are more that could be helped. Is that a question of the local authority working with the community welfare officers and the Department of Social Protection? How do they co-ordinate on those issues?

I echo Senator Rabbitte. There is a diversity in how much local authorities interact with other State bodies or take these things seriously. Particularly in Dublin, I am acutely aware of how debilitating housing costs and provision have become for so many people.

As Mr. Hand said, we work closely with all the local authorities and there are excellent people in them that we work with. We work with the same aim. The local authorities have the main responsibility for provision of housing support. HAP and RAS are the two main ones. We have seen the rent supplement numbers go down significantly as HAP has taken over that responsibility but we still have, I think, about 6,000 rent supplements in payment.

It is approximately 6,000 and we still get about 100 new applications per week. It is a short-term supplement to allow somebody to apply for HAP or to get somebody who is out of work for a short period over the line.

While a person is on rent supplement, there is close engagement with the local authority with a view to moving them towards longer-term support on HAP, so that transition is seamless. In a case where a person loses employment for a short period because of illness, they are not a HAP person. The purpose of rent supplement there is to prevent additional financial pressure. Where there is a need, we would start that transitional piece, working closely with the local authority. We have a number of dedicated people on the homeless side and there are working relationships locally. We have excellent working relationships and there are no obstacles.

That is a really important initiative. We have a CWO embedded in the Dublin Region Homeless Executive who works as part of its multidisciplinary team structure to assist in some hard-edged cases and work on the resolution of issues across the local authorities, working with other agencies as well.

The interaction on rent supplement with the local authorities typically happens at an individual case level. Somebody may be going for HAP or having difficulty. It happens on a fairly regular basis. It is so the person does not fall through the cracks on either side. In some cases I have seen, there is really proactive involvement to get the person a solution. We are seeing cases where people are starting to get into rent arrears or difficulties in getting their place resolved.
I thank Mr. Hand. Are there any other comments or questions from members?
I have a very brief one.
You were just in time.
It would be neglectful of you not to let me in.

I recall the process to apply for humanitarian assistance after Storm Éowyn. From the initial announcement to when people were substituting applications, the rules changed from the start to the finish. That caused a lot of annoyance. It was the first time in many of our lives that it had to happen but if we are to have another storm of that significance, I anticipate the witnesses' processes would be somewhat more streamlined. Would that be fair to say?

The word "unprecedented" has become meaningless in a way, but it was unprecedented in terms of the effect, the impact and the requirement to stand people out on the ground. The first priority in the days following the storm was to provide income support for people who needed it. People ended up homeless, there were houses damaged, etc. I agree there were a lot of lessons learned from Storm Éowyn. It is much more streamlined. A significant number of people were paid. It ended up at nearly 60,000. For a storm and humanitarian aid scheme, that is a complete outlier in terms of the support we have provided over the years. It was a very stressful time. I commend the team on the community welfare side who stood up and got people paid. There are lessons learned.
Excellent. I can guarantee the witnesses probably got no request for support with an ESB bill during that time.
Unfortunately.

I thank Ms Goodwin, Mr. Hand and Ms Haran for their contributions today and for providing the briefing materials in advance. We very much appreciate it. It is very important to have a discussion about the CWS. It is something the members brought up and something we raised with the Minister when he was in here. This is how today's meeting came to be arranged. I thank the witnesses for taking time out of their schedule to be here with us today.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 11.30 a.m. sine die.
